example.pack.title: Examples of Preimage of a Function
example.pack.caption: Preimage of a Function

statement.para: Find the preimage of y\in \RNr of the function

answer.para: In this case we can use geometric reasoning to answer this problem: f sends a point (u,v) to the number u^2+v^2. This is the square of the distance of (u,v) from the origin. Therefore

li.para: The preimage of y=0 in \RNr is the origin (0,0).
The preimage of y>0 in \RNr is the circle in \RNr[2] centered at (0,0) of radius \sqrt{y}.
The preimage of y< 0 is empty; i.e. the equation f(u,v)=y has no solution if y<0 .

info.para: This black circle has radius 1. It forms the preimage of 1, denoted f^{-1}(1).
This purple circle has radius \sqrt{2}. It forms the preimage of 2, denoted f^{-1}(2).
This blue circle has radius \sqrt{3}. It forms the preimage of 3, denoted f^{-1}(3).
This yellow circle has radius 2. It forms the preimage of 4, denoted f^{-1}(4).

statement.para: Find the preimage of the number k under the function

answer.para: We need to solve the equation 2x+y = k. This equation is linear. So we know that the solutions form a line in \RNr[2], which is perpendicular to the vector \Vect{n} = (2,1).

Thus we see that the preimage of a colored dot on the right is the line of the same color on the left. This implies that the function transforms each of the colored lines on the left into the single point of the same color on the right.
